title: NodeMcu and 5v Single Channel Relay Enclosure

description.text:
ESP8266 Module ESP-12E NodeMcu LUA WiFi and a single channel 5V relay switch. Just needed something to hold the parts together conformable because I built this into a internet remote control for my garage door opener. Worked well and the lid snaps on and is very tight. I had a hard time taking it back apart.

UPDATE: I created a second version of the lid without the pegs. They work but some printers might not be able to get the detail right. On the second version there is a extending tab that will get close to the NodeMCU and keep it from flopping around. I did not add one on the relay side because I planned on a tab of hot glue on the bottom.

Also you may note that the relay is a but off center. I wanted the relay to be pinched to the side for stability. That was my design choice.

I hope you enjoy this very specific project box.

Thinking about making some wings so you can screw down this project box. Let me know if there is any interest.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

No

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1Hn4VODfJqV

title: Inmoov Hand derivat from different creators

description.text:
Hi my try to change the original hands from Gael Langevin with those two role models:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:118031 from Gael Langevin
and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:318671.

The aim is to get rid of the line tensions and reduce the weight of the forearm.
The motor is a mini geared motor and the worm is from a glue stick.
The original fingers from Gael are of the same size so I made my own 3 sizes.
One size for the index, middle and ring-finger. One size for the pinky and one size for the thumb (but this is not printed yet).
All created from the original stl files from Gael Langevin
and sized with 123d Design from Autodesk.

The motor driver is a dismounted cheap servo, so i use the electronic and the poti wich is integrated into the axis of the finger.

comments.text: Hey deine Internet Seite ist für mich übers Handy nicht erreichbar..
comments.author: swap81

comments.text:
Hi
die hatte ich auch schon gesehen aber die Gewindekonstruktion hatte ich auch auf meiner Webseite bereits ausprobiert http://roboter.mindach.net.
Ich habe mit der chinesischen Plattform Probleme denn alles was mehr als 5 $ kostet muss beim Zoll angemeldet werden und kostet dann entsprechend Einfuhrzoll.
Die Geschwindigkeit muss dann bei mindestens 1000 rpm liegen. Dann ist aber die Kraft zu klein. Daher die Schnecke vom Klebestift
und der Motor mit einer höheren Kraft. Jetzt bewegt sich der Finger relativ realistisch auf und zu.

Die Prittstiftalternative habe ich gewählt weil ich eine Schnecke mit einem Durchmesser von 3 mm nicht mit meinem Ultimaker 2 drucken kann. Einen Servo habe ich nicht eingebaut aber ich habe ein 10 Euro Servo demontiert und einen Motor mit Getriebe genommen den ich
an der Stelle des Servomotors angelötet habe. Das Servopoti habe ich in die Wurzel des Fingers gepackt. Damit kann das ganze auch mit MRL angesteuert werden.
Die Finger sind aus der Idee von Langevin prosthetic Hand entstanden. Nur fand ich das Getriebe und die Servos im Original zu groß.
Wenn der Sommer vorbei ist werde ich mich auch wieder dem bau des Roboters zuwenden.

author: dsgra

title: Tricopter RcExplorer Mod for Short Shaft and Tail Bearings

description.text:
This is a remix of TriCopter RC Explorer V.2 for support of short shaft motors (4 holes) and adds thrust bearings for tail rotation. I use NTM Prop Drive Series motors from hobby king. 800kv and 1200kv have been successful with previous tri's and quad's. The motor bolt patterns are compatible with the aluminum mounts provided in the accessory kit for the NTM short shaft motors. Please see the Instructions for parts lists. I will add some photos of finished product and assembly diagrams soon. This is a work in progress: It has not flown yet. This was created with TinkerCad: You can copy and modify here:
  • FrontMountR Mod
  • FrontMountL Mod
  • Tricoper Tail Servo Mount Bushing Mod
  • Tricoper Tail Motor Mount Mod

In addition to the parts other than motors as specified in the original work ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:67010/#instructions ) the following or similar parts are needed for this modification. Motors:
  • 3x NTM Prop Drive Series 28-26A 1200kv / 286w (short shaft version) (or similar, 800kv to 1400kv should be ok)
  • 3x NTM Prop Drive 28 Series Accessory Pack
    • Bearing:
  • 1 pair HK-500GT Thrust Bearing 12 x 5 x 4mm
  • 1/10 4x40mm Countersunk Screw with shank

title: SmartRap X and Y motor fishing line spool

description.text: For those of you who have D-shaped stepper motor shafts here's a rough attempt to resolve this issue (I have this problem too).  The little holes on the outer flanges allow you to thread your line so that when you wind it, there is no slip.  3 to 4 windings should be more than enough.  I will try to print this and see how it works.  I have a hole and slot for a 2.5mm grub/set screw and nut as well.  I have no idea how this will affect accuracy but the working diameter of the spool is 10mm, so I am hoping that it should not have that much of an effect, but I have no way of knowing how that affects the 1.8 degree steps on this print.  The only alternative I can offer now is drinking straw superglued to the shaft and then you wind around that.  The two halves of this spool should be superglued together before installing.

print_settings.Notes:: .4mm Nozzle use up to 3 perimeters for the 1.2, or up to 5 perimeters for the 2.2

description.text:
This is a small stacking storage bin that can be printed as is or scaled to meet your needs.

The basic size is 1 inch tall x 2 inches wide x 3 inches long (25.4mm x 50.8mm x 76.2mm).

There are two versions loaded which allow for up to 1.2mm wall thickness or 2.2mm wall thickness. If you print the 1.2mm version and you have a .4mm nozzle you would print with 3 perimeters. This will produce a storage bin that nest snugly inside each other.

Set your slicer settings for the bottom thickness of your choice, 2 or 3 perimeters, and 0 top layers.

You can scale the size in your slicer if you want a larger storage bin, If you want a smaller bin you can scale down but you need to reduce the wall perimeters as well to allow stacking.

This is designed as a solid so that you can decide how thick to make your walls for your application. 2 Perimeters should be sufficient for the designed size and 3 provides a nice snug fit with a bit more strength.

Wanhao Duplicator I3 V2.1

title: Case for LCsoft CY7C68013A logic analyser clone

description.text: I got one of these cheap boards on ebay (~Â£9) in the hopes of using it as a cheap saleae clone. Apparently I need to swap out the eeprom first, and I'll need to add some zeners for protection, but here's the base for now.

Print, drill/push out the m3 holes in the corners, add nuts to base. I had to sand the sides of my board ever so slightly to get it to fit - while I could have resized the scad, the cheap board had raggedy edges so I didn't mind filing them anyway. It should be very easy to design a lid for this, but it'll depend on what extra circuitry you want in the case.

comments.text:
I have the same logic analyzer. I have added an EEPROM to store the VID/PID for Saleae and I use the onboard EEPROM for USBee ZX. With a switch I am able to select if I want to use it as a USBee or a Saleae without desoldering anything.

text = Demetri

A common misconception about 3D printing is that it is limited by size, which in some respects I understand. Most printers are under a foot cubed, however many parts can be put together to make much bigger product.

Software-
For all of my projects, I use Autodesk Fusion 360. It is a free design software tool that allows user to store files on the cloud. This allows you to access files from any computer with a wifi connection. All in all, Fusion 360 is truly the software program of the future.

Autodesk Fusion 360 Free Download → http://autode.sk/2sx9WHh

Boxzy-
This project was made using a Boxzy CNC machine. It is a versatile desktop machine that allows you to 3D print, CNC mill, and laser etch just with the swap of a head.

Use Promo Code SHELF to get free shipping on your Boxzy machine → http://bit.ly/2sjREXR

Print List
4 Top Front Brackets~ 4topAngled.stl
4 Top Back Brackets ~ 4topRight.stl
16 Angled Supports ~ 16angledShelfSupports

4 Back Angle Brackets ~ 4PieceBackBracket.stl

title: E3D V6 Direct Drive Mount with BLTouch Mount

description.text:
I created a new mount for the FolgerTech i3 2020 to attach an E3D V6 hot end. The mount includes features to attach a BLTouch sensor, and there are accessory mount points on the opposite side for attaching a fan or other object if you so desire.

One of the images shows how I oriented the parts for printing. I printed with supports with the BLTouch sensor mount down.

I have updated the files with V2 of the STL files, and I've provided a G-code that works for my i3 style printer. I had to make some slight changes to the dimensions of the mount to fit the E3D with V2. I've been using it on my printer for several weeks now, and it works. The BL touch might not be at the right height, so it may require some spacers / shimming to get it tuned in properly.

Printer:

FolgerTech i3 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Designed in fusion 360

I designed this in Autodesk Fusion 360 under the enthusiast license.

comments.text: What are the benefits of mounting the extruder this way over the stock configuration?
comments.author: anthony_sleck

comments.text:
It will take some of the strain off of the bowden tube and help decrease under and over extrusion. It will also help with the cooling of the stepper by not enclosing it and allowing free air to move around it.
This one used a NEMA17 bracket I got with the extruder upgrade. You can use it or you can use one of the others versions of this that have popped up. I did this bracket to not have any supports and be simple. Your call.

author: anthony_sleck

description.text:
Say good bye to those days of torturing your fingers while levelling the bed on the CR-10, here I remixed a previous version and I made a bigger knob attachment for manual levelling that it's easy to grab and still fits perfectly under the printer bed without obtrusion. I hope you find it useful as a did.

INSTALLATION NOTES: Unscrew the bed knob off the bed COMPLETELY, you'll notice the printed knob has a round collar. The bed knob has a round lip. Fit the collar of the printed knob into the lip on the bed knob then screw back on with that side facing up. This will prevent the wheel from falling off in middle print.
I made this in 3ds Max since I don't know how to use other CAD programs yet

description.text: This was made because my camper's under storage latches keep breaking, but just the top part and then only the hold tab. There was no need to make the base because the part that keeps breaking is the end tab of the top latch not the one bottom one which is usually attached with rivets. I suspect that this should fit most standard latches. just use the same hardware that was in the original and install it in the new one. I took the RV Latch made by marcsulf, and published Jun 5, 2012 and made it narrower so that the tabs would fit my camper's base, then I added side rails to keep the same outside appearance. By the way, thanks marcsulf for publishing your part, it saved me a lot of work not to mention $15. Thanks This thing was made with Tinkercad. description.text:
The best thumb caps that you can find for 608 bearings!

They are threaded with a thread pitch that is easy to use and strong, not that press fit garbage.

-EDIT-

Added a version without circles so you can customize on your own.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

I use 100% infill as it makes the bolt side of the caps much stronger and it doesn't add much time/material to the print.

I would suggest printing at least 2 sets at a time or adding it to your print at the moment. This gives the caps enough time to cool down between layers. If you don't do this the bolt side of the caps will have issues.

Cleanup

Whatever your printer leaves for drool from crossing between the two parts you'll need to cleanup to make sure it'll fit in the 8mm bearing. The 'nut' side of the caps is actually 7.8 and it barely fits, i'm sure this is due to me being a novice. After using a knive to clean up the drool I take an emry board to smooth out any other imperfections.

Found 999 wrong ways to make a thumb cap....

I've had several revisions that were borderline OK, some I've used for dozens of spinners. But I decided to look into the things that I hated most about the caps. The fact when you are trying to work them in to each other you'll wear out the ends of your thumbs from threading and un-threading back and forth. This is the reason for the dimples around the rim.

title: QAV_R motor guard (with Dual material Print)

description.text: My remix of a Motor guard for my QAV-R quadcopter frame. In TinkerCad I merged together the guard from Sl33py Dog (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1668742) with mounting holes from meoster (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1416929). I wanted the mounts to be able to withstand a crash and I had a sample of Ninjaflex so I printed the whole guard. Unfortunately using Ninjaflec I was unable to tighten the motor screws without pushing all the way through the flexible material. So I decided to try to make a dual PLA/ Ninjaflex print. Using meshmixer I sliced the model so the bottom 2/3 of the mount would be PLA and the rest would be Ninjaflex. Using ReplicatorG I created gcode for both parts and merged them. To get good prints with the Ninjaflex I need a lot of heat and slow printing. Used 240 degrees for the flexible filament temperature, it oozes, but under this temperature and I can't seem to get good extrusion. For printing speed I used 30mm/s with 60mm/s travel with the PLA profile selected, this was too fast, so I ended up manually slowing the print speed down to 65% using the onscreen menu during printing. Came out better than I thought they would, good adhesion between PLA and Ninjaflex.

description.text:
I got this Idea from Opossums and his LED Bridge Light https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1639224
I really needed something like his only much smaller and scalable to fit my LED strip.
I made this light for my soldering projects to give me optimal lighting of my circuit boards without shadows and without the light beaming in my face. It sits about 7.5 inches tall and is 15 inches wide of working space.
would also be a great reading or desk light!

What youll need is:
LED strip Like this: https://www.amazon.com/Flexible-Non-waterproof-Christmas-Decoration-Daylight/dp/B00HSF65MC/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid=1498664687&sr=8-6&keywords=led+strip+lights
and a 1A 12V power supply similar to this one: https://www.amazon.com/Adapter-Power-Supply-2-1mm-listed/dp/B016APVKO8/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1498664737&sr=8-2-spons&keywords=12v+power+supply&psc=1.
Print using the given setting below for the best outcome. I used a dental tool to clean out the support material of the rails. I used sper glue to glue togather the rails. You may need an exact o knife to cut away odd shapes of the nubs to get the pieces to fit nice and snug.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

20

Infill:

25

Notes:

Print on the side for the arc light rail bars and print up right for the 2 end stands. use full support on the arc beams. not necessary and it is hard to clean if you do full support on the end stands. to clean the inside of the rails of Support material I used a dental tool to easily scrap it out.

dental tool to clean out support material wasn't to bad to dig out I strung out the lights through the rails first before gluing together. I used rubber bands on the ends to help hold the light as the glue cured.

title: Riemen Extruder für Bowden und flexieblem Material / Belt driven Extruder for Bowden and flex material
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ich hab einen Extruder benötigt, welcher folgende Eigenschaften hat:

  • thermische Entkoppelung Motor / Antriebsrad
  • einfach zu drucken
  • Bowden
  • alle Materialien
  • präzise
  • integrierte Filamentreinigung
  • einfacher Filamentwechsel
  • alle Materialien müssen vorhanden sein (bin halt Schwabe)

Da ich keinen auf Thingiverse gefunden hab, konstruierte ich diesen. Ich habe die Antriebswelle mit einem MK Antriebsrad ausgestattet. Ich habe das grössere genommen (12mm) da durch den grösseren Radius mehr Zähnchen in das Filament greifen (auch wenn man teilweise gegenteiliges im Internet ließt).

Als Riemen hab ich einen GT2 gewählt. Untersetzung ist 3:1. Riemen deshalb. Ich halte diesen für präzieser und er trennt die Wärme Antriebsrad / Motor.

Ich habe meinen mit PLA gedruckt, ohne Support. Probiert hab ich es schon mit folgenden Materialien:

  • PLA
  • ABS
  • PETG
  • Ninaflex
  • Igludur (spezielles Gleitmaterial)

Der Bowden geht direkt bis zum Antriebsrad. Im CAD hat es sich besser zuschneiden lassen, als dann in der Werkstatt :-)

Statt ein Pushfit hab ich ein Gewinde auf den Schlauch geschnitten und anschließend die Muttern draufgedreht. Wichtig: anschließend mit einem Bohrer wieder aufbohren. Der Bowden verengt sich an dieser Stelle etwas, so dass das Filament nicht mehr durch passt.

Das Filament wechseln ist ganz einfach. Einfach auf den Hebel drücken. Dann lässt sich das Filament rein / raus schieben.

Material:

  • GT2 - Rad 60Z
  • GT2 - Rad 20Z
  • GT2 - Riemen 156mm einfache Länge
  • alle Schrauben am Körper M4
  • alle Schrauben Schlauchbefestigung M3
  • MK Antriebsrad, Zahngrund 11mm Durchmesser

------------------ Google Translate ------------
I need an extruder which has the following properties:

  • thermal decoupling motor / drive wheel
  • easy to print
  • Bowden
  • all materials
  • precise
  • integrated filament cleaning
  • easy filament change
  • all materials must be available in my home

Since I have not found one on Thingiverse, I constructed this. I have the drive shaft equipped with a MK drive wheel. I have taken the bigger (12mm) because by the larger radius more teeth in the filament grasp (even if one partially in the opposite is left on the Internet).

As a belt I've chosen a GT2. The substitution is 3: 1. Belt therefore. I think this is more precise and it separates the heat drive wheel / engine.

I have my PLA printed without support. I tried it with the following materials:

  • PLA
  • SECTION
  • PETG
  • Ninaflex
  • Igludur (special lubrication material)
    http://www.igus.de/3d-print-material/3d-druck-material

The Bowden goes directly to the drive wheel. In the CAD it was better to cut than in the workshop :-)

Instead of a pushfit I have a thread on the hose cut and then the nuts draufgedreht. Important: drill again with a drill. The Bowden narrows at this point, so that the filament no longer fits through.

Changing the filament is easy. Simply press the lever. Then the filament can be pushed in / out.

Material:

  • GT2 wheel 60Z
  • GT2 wheel 20Z
  • GT2 - Strap 156mm easy length
  • all screws on body M4
  • all screws M3 hose attachment
  • MK drive wheel, tooth base 11mm diameter

print_settings.Notes::
Print multiples at a time for full sets, ions and chains separately. Use brim when printing multiple pieces for more secure adhesion.
-When using the pause function, park the print head well out of the way to make magnet insertion easier.
-Export your gcode file and use a text editor to search for the "M0" pause command. This should be at the beginning of the layer at which the cavities are sealed up. Use Cura's layer view to know what layer number that is on your slice.

description.text:
Make learning chemistry more hands-on and tangible with Crosslinkers models!

Manipulative models demonstrate the process of polymer crosslinking for fun, hands-on demonstrations in class or at home.

Embedded magnets demonstrate the attraction of polymer active sites and ions to cause polymer chain growth!.

Ionic crosslinking is a common method of producing cell-filled hydrogels and drug delivery mechanisms using sodium alginate and calcium cations.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Use Cura's "Pause at Height" function to pause the print at the appropriate height to insert magnets into cavities in the print:

10.8 pause height for chains
13.25 pause height for ions

!!!!CRITICAL!!!!
When inserting magnets, insert into chains with south end of magnet facing outward, and north out for ions. This causes the ions to only bind to chains and not to one another.

Helpful printing tips:

  • Print multiples at a time for full sets, ions and chains separately. Use brim when printing multiple pieces for more secure adhesion.
    -When using the pause function, park the print head well out of the way to make magnet insertion easier.
    -Export your gcode file and use a text editor to search for the "M0" pause command. This should be at the beginning of the layer at which the cavities are sealed up. Use Cura's layer view to know what layer number that is on your slice.
None!

Designing in browser in Onshape! Hidden edges for embedded magnet cavities Use Cura's ghost function to preview the cavities inside the solid model Use Cura's layer view to see at what layer the cavities will be sealed up

Polarity Objects of opposite charges will be attracted to each other and stick together (just like magnets) Temperature At higher temperatures, molecules move around faster and interact more. At lower temperatures, molecules move slower and interact less. Ionic crosslinking Negatively charged chains stick to positively charged ion balls and form larger, connected networks of linked chains

The Plan 15 min - Discuss necessary background material
20 min - Run the experiment! Write down all observations of the crosslinking process relative to temperature and how chains and ions link up to form polymer networks
15 min - Class discussion and practical application of ionic crosslinking
3D printing filament and small magnets such as neodymium magnets

• 3d printing
  • ionic crosslinking
  • temperature modeling
50 minutes
Print models Print all models with embedded magnets Run the experiment! See attached experiment procedure.
Class specific

Academic papers on Alginate crosslinking http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0144861711001068
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3538854/

title: Howard Mike Golden Age Racer scalemodel (sample)

description.text:
This is a sample of my commercial model Howard Mike Golden Age Air Racer, you can find the complete model in this link:

http://cults3d.com/es/artilugios/fiat-600-scale-model

For more models visit my cults3D page:

https://cults3d.com/es/usuarios/guaro3d/creaci%C3%B3n

Follow me on Instagram: @guaro3D

This is a scale model of the Howard Mike Golden Age Air Racer in 1/48 scale, I have printed is this scale and overall its an easy print, but some pieces do get very small. You could also scale it up by 1.5 to get a 1/32 scale model, or by 2 to get a 1/24 scale model.

It has many details and it looks great once printed. It has been carefully designed to be a replica of the real one. It would make a great show off model.

All the stel files have aligned for easy print.

Happy printing!

comments.text: I had a chance to look at quite a few of your models and all I can say is that you are one talented individual! I have been in scale modeling since I can remember but totally dedicated for the past 8 years. I am retired due to health so I get to model quite a bit. The reason that I am making comment on this is I have this dream on printing either a 1/32 or 1/24 scale Northrop Gamma 2A. One of many hand spinners I modeled and printed for a friend a few months ago. The two voids can be filled with heavy tungsten balls (2-4mm diameter). This model was made to fit this hybrid ceramic bearing from Acer Racing: https://www.acerracing.com/index.php?p=product&id=612&parent=30&is_print_version=true

Directions

  1. Fill two cavities with small tungsten balls (better two weight out each side with a scale for balance).

  2. Use a small amount of superglue to secure tungsten spheres in cavities.

  3. Make sure that both sides are flat (may need to sand if tungsten balls are protruding).

  4. Align two sides and use adhesive (superglue) to fix both sides together.

  5. Finish by sanding outside of spinner to smooth surface.

Note: since tungsten balls are necessarily the cheapest if you mis-align the sides while gluing or are not happy with the final product you can use a torch to melt the plastic housing and recover the tungsten weights. I designed these to be loaded with tungsten weights as it's extremely dense (~17500 kg/m^3) and non-toxic. I would recommend staying away from lead (Pb) shot if possible.

Stepper-driven extruders have great consistency, but the cost of the motor and motor driver can be prohibitive. This is a simple, unregulated DC motor design that relies on excessively powerful torque from a 12V 30RPM gearmotor from Jaycar. It will drive 3mm PLA faster than I feel comfortable with. It uses the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2192 mendel_misc.inc include file.

The motor's 4mm output shaft has a flat, and this is used to help anchor a knurled M4 nut with a 4mm hole drilled in it. Punching and solder are used to fill in the flat and anchor the nut to the output shaft.
A couple of 16mm M8 washers and a 608 bearing are held on a 40mm M8 bolt with a wing nut. The wing nut must have one side filed flat to fit next to the motor. This bearing is movable due to deliberate slack in the mounting hole.
The motor is inserted into the extruder body output shaft first, and the knurled nut is aligned with the filament hole. A 40mm M4 machine screw, two washers and a nut are used to clamp the motor in place.
The unit then behaves much like a stepper-driven extruder from here, but can be driven by PWM 12V DC.

description.text: A quick n dirty coil winder that I needed for a non-disclosed prototype machine I am currently designing.. It works pretty well for my needs, it's not that accurate using the steppers I am using, but it does the work! I designed this very fast, so the source might not be that clean and it's not structured perfectly, but really I didn't care, I just needed something that works, fast; same thing for the PCB it can use some love.. :P For example, removing the delays in the stepper code and replacing this with a event driver driver would be much more efficient, but it didn't create a big problem for my needs.. *** First prototype, now it's better than this with the enhanced pointer, but it gives an idea: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oK3u5CCnO1k

Print all parts.

  • Find 2 stepper motor that fits (I had 2 PM42S laying around, might not be the best choice, they are not that powerful, but it works)

  • Get all parts you need for the PCB: 2 limit switches, LM052L compatible LCD, ATMEGA168, l298n driver, LM317 regulator, DC jack, PS2 port, Switch, 16 Diodes (1N4007 or better), SB340 Diode or equivalent, some resistors (values in pcb file), led, some filtering caps.. Values are not critical, except maybe for the lm317 resistors which are 720 and 240 ohms and for the current limiting resistors on the l298n, I simply put a bare jumper because I honestly didn't care about over current.. :P

  • Assemble parts together using M3 bolts and nuts.

  • Build mcrocontroler code with AVRStudio5

  • Flash using ISP on board

  • Plug in a PS2 keyboard, Plug in a DC Adapter (not critical, ~12 volts)

  • Switch on machine, let it calibrate, configure in the menus and enjoy!
    • WARNING: There's a dirty hack in the PS2 port on the PCB.. I wired incorrectly some pins and I quickly hacked them by reversing the bottom (green) layer! .. I print on single sided pcb, so I simply put wires and solder them for the other layer, so for me it wasn't a problem since I don't print a full layer.. If you want to print the other layer, you'll have to fix this little "issue", anyways if anyone is indeed interested in printing it and don't know how to fix it, simply ask me, I'll fix it for you, now I'm too lazy to fix it, so the time to explain this to you is well, as long as making the fix :(

title: GPU Vent Stand for Mining Cryptocurrency

description.text:
I realised soon after that propping GPUs on tilt to vent the hot air just wasn't going to cut it.

This design allows me to set a number of GPUs next to a desktop rig with no need to fabricate mining rig frames.

Useful for those mining on smaller scale with just a couple additional GPUs and not a full blown 5 or 6 GPU setup.

In the picture is a 3 GPU rig, 1 card in chassis and 2 outside on the GPU vent stand.

Future model for mounting on vertical board to be added soon.

Hope you find this useful :)

Cheers!
-Ed

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Solid

Notes:

Printed with full infill but I am sure it will be fine at 90%.
Print using ABS as the card vent does get warm.

comments.text: It works great :)
comments.author: joseshiru

comments.text: I think these GPU coolers are designed to push air in through the fan, and out the IO side. It would be somewhat more efficient to have your stand upside down. This is because the less dense hot air that you pump out the bottom will rise up and some will go back into the system though the fan. By having it upside down you will get more cooler air coming into the GPU and therefore cooler temps when mining.

So i was nearly done with my other gimbal holderand i found some old dampers i got a while ago with a lasercut gimbal. These are easy to get dampers commonly used on the rail style mounting systems also it's cheap and this build needs less material and it keeps the camera closer. As always this is a WIP.
I'll update when it's ready
The STL's and the Freecad files should be online now. EDIT: Just finished the "smarter" plate and i got a new idea..... as always. So this is now the "smartest" plate, it fixes the gimbal on top of the frame instead of in front of it.
So CG goes a bit back too wich is a good thing considering the deadcat kit i'm using. It gives the motor some few mm clearance and also gives the driverboard for the gimbal a place. alltogether not a bad build and it works like a charm!
print and assemble, you need a set of 4 nuts and bolts maybe some rivets to match.

If your throttle tube has enough space to the housing, this will fit perfectly without removing anything. There is a notch on the honda throttle tube, so the throttle lock can just slide in. That's why they are in 2 parts, and just a dab of super glue is needed to fit them.

Choose between the 2.4mm and the 2.0mm part based on the clearance.
Use at your own risk.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TanYgkaf0bU

title: dodecahedron lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
this is a lamp consisting of 12 pentagonal parts
the top part contains a ring for light bulb attachment the side parts do not have a interlocking mechanism, so they must be held together somehow (intentionally i designed holes at the edges for that but than i used small metal clips to hold the structure together) the top part has some hooks that hold the structure for fast access to change the light bulb UPDATE: i replaced the metal clips with some golden wire and connected the pieces at the corner -> much more stability and better looking :)
i also used another light bulb to cast harder defined shadows, its definitely worth it!

print 11 side parts and come up with a good idea to connect them, because they do not hold together on their one ;-)  
print 1 top part

print_settings.Notes:: Normal settings for any material will work fine. Make sure to include rafts/support and print it right-side up.

description.text:
Here's a project from a year ago where we took photos of an officer's badge and recreated it in 3D.

It was a bit of a test, and the model is a bit rough - but it is pretty cool!

We printed it for him and many of his fellow officers to take as gifts for their generosity.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Normal settings for any material will work fine. Make sure to include rafts/support and print it right-side up.

We used some photo-capturing techniques and ran it through software that stitches together 2D images and forms them into 3D models.

Pretty cool technique.

title: Subaru Justy alloy rim center cap

description.text:
A replacement center cap for OEM Subaru Justy alloy rim.
Do NOT print them from PLA I'm sure the heat from brakes will melt it...
I printed them from ABS and paint them with filler spray, silver metalic paint and clear coat (the same like I used on the rims...). And I added a little Subaru sticker (I have them custom made...)
I also used some zinc plated steel wire to make a spring that holds it in the rim.
I also make a full set...

description.text: This is a letter-shaped token for the card game, "Love Letter" by AEG. The game comes with small cubes to keep score each round. These letter-shaped tokens with a hear on them add to the love letter theme.
Model 1918 155mm "Schneider" Howitzer Scale 1:56
My brother wanted to make a motorized version. so I had to remove the text to make a motor mounting surface.

I have a challenge for someone to try. I really suck at repairing video game models for 3D Printing and have this MOD I released on the Nexus and Steam years ago for skyrim. I had modified the file created by someone else called the Soulfrost Greatsword. I never heard from or saw the person again but he had created an awesome Broad Sword with crappy stats. After giving me permission to make changes he disappeared. Anyway the point is he had made an adaptation of Frostmorne from WOW and I would like to print it for myself. I'm posting it here to share but it is not printable at this time. Can someone help by remixing it? I would love to see Angus from Makers Muse or Jerry from Barnaclese Nerdgasm get a crack at this as I know they love great looking game weapons.

title: Canada 150 Logo in 3D

description.text:
A colourful 3D version of the Canada's Sesquicentennial logo from official licensee Makerwiz, Canada's 3D expert. Now you can add some diamonds to your flag waving on Canada Day and beyond!

Our Canada 150 Logo in 3D was printed on BEETHEFIRST 3D Printer (from BEEVERYCREATIVE) using BEESUPPLIES PLA filaments of the corresponding colours as specified in the file names.

The Canada 150 logo was originally created by Ariana Cuvin from Toronto, Ontario. The logo was the winning design in a nation-wide competition among design students, and was chosen from over 300 eligible entries.

description.text: I used this model as a way to practice tolerances in Fusion 360. The wheel is made to be pieced with a standard skate board bearing. The car wont break any speed records but it works lol. I recommend low infill settings to keep the weight low. Only use the Tire files if you can print in flexible filament. I didn't need to use glue but I did use a lot of force to snap the axles into the bearings.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

All parts can have large layers.

Infill:

low

The axles snap into the bearings after being placed through the holes in the car. No glue is necessary. I didn't use supports, the wheels may or may not need them depending on how much time you want to spend getting out support material. I recommend printing the wheels bearing side up so it fits better

description.text:
This is a simple, standard 16mm die.

There are two versions of the die:
-Single Extrusion (first image above)
-Dual Extrusion (second and third image above)

NOTE: All STL files are watermarked to secure the intellectual property of my 3D models. To learn more about watermarking 3D files, visit www.watermark3d.com

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

+0.1 mm

Infill:

70-100%

Notes:

Single Extrusion
I recommend orienting the die so that the one-dot is on the bottom. There is no need for support.

(Using 100% infill and 0.1mm layer thickness, it took 46min to print).

Dual Extrusion
When printing the die, I recommend using an ooze shield as well as a skirt/brim. Also, make sure that you have retractions turned on (I didn't and you can see in the image above how it turned out). No support will be needed for this die.

I decided to print my die at 100% infill just to make things easier, but if you want to print a die that is exactly the same weight as a real die, use 70% infill.

Real Die = 4.1g
3D Printed Die (70% Infill) = 4.1g
3D Printed Die (80% Infill) = 4.4g
3D Printed Die (90% Infill) = 4.7g
3D Printed Die (100% Infill) = 5g

(Using 100% infill and 0.1mm layer thickness, it took 1hr and 14min to print).

Dual Extrusion Die

After the print finishes, you might need to sand/file the die as there were several zits and blobs.

title: Coffee Stencil - Telephone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Edit 6/30/2017: Ring-Ring...Who is it?...Brand new stencil holder for you:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2412238

Edit 6/29/2017: I've created a new stencil of a butterfly, with a new handle design! All new stencils going forward will have this improved design, and I will retrofit all previous stencils shortly....

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2410534

--End of Edits--

Ahh telephones. Before the advent of cordless and cellular phones, people used telephones with handsets, and on a very common AT&T/Bell Telephone handset was a receiver that had a very distinctive (and cool) pattern. One dot in the center, six around that, then just keep adding six until you have four layers. (1 / 6 / 12 / 18) Now, this is the 21st century, so I decided to kick the pattern up a notch and, yup, that's right: add a fifth layer, making the pattern 1, 6, 12, 18 and 24. I was so busy, I had someone else count the pips for me, but the math works out, and boy is it pretty!

I realized after I posted this that someone might be "advanced" enough (extra points if you get the reference) to think that this coffee looks enough like a telephone microphone that they put a full mug of scalding hot coffee up to their ear. It might sound like this: "Hellooooooo-ooowwwww" And then that would immediately slide into an expletive, most likely starting with an "F." (Try saying that at home. It's surprisingly rewarding.) Then third degree burns. But seriously: no burning hot coffee on your face or ears or anywhere else on your body unless you're into that. Thanks!

Speaking of telephones, GlaDOS in the video game Portal once said this and it made me laugh:

I feel awful about that surprise. Tell you what, let's give your parents a call right now. [phone ringing] The birth parents you are trying to reach do not love you. Please hang up. [Dial tone]

But seriously, this stencil looks almost like an old-timey telephone microphone, so your coffee will be extra nostalgic if you're an old like me!

This is the last of the old-series of stencils. I'm posting this on the day that I've reworked the stencil with better handles, and a few new features. Don't worry - there will eventually be a newer version of this stencil released, but it won't have a different pattern, just happier handles!

I literally just had a root canal an hour ago, so I'm going to keep this short.

Oh, one last thing: If you have a larger/smaller mug, cup, glass or other assorted vessel that this stencil just won't work with, please let me know the dimensions of the item, and I'll make a new set of stencils just for you! Well, and everyone else, too. It helps if you print one of these stencils off, and then create an I Made One, so you can send me pictures of why it isn't working, what your vessel looks like (isn't that a rather personal question?) and its dimensions. The most important dimensions are the outside and inside diameter. The rest is just me being curious. I'll make sure the lip fits around the outside diameter, and that there's enough of a margin between the stencil cut-outs and the inside diameter. Please share measurements in metric - millimeters is best. Thanks!

Also, I will happily take ideas for stencils! Just send me comments here, or a private message on the system. I will use the idea, and if it's not already in the pipeline, give you credit in the Summary, because you're awesome! Here are some ideas I currently have in the pipeline:

Coming up Next: The Secret Surprise Thing!

After that: Butterfly!

Then in no particular order: Dog Bone, Dog Print, Cat Print, Radioactive, Fallout Shelter, Recycling Logo, Maybe a Dolphin or a Whale...who knows?

Here are all the previous stencils:

Heart: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2393694
Smiley Face: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2400553
Five-Pointed Star: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2395326
Five-Petaled Flower: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2396760
Leaf: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2405021
Peace Symbol: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2402130

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Prints like a dream. Just level your bed and it should work fine. The holes are big enough that there shouldn't be a lot of excess stringing inside, but if you have a problem with stringing, the holes are easy enough to ream out. Probably easier to fix your stringing problem, which is usually retraction? Here's a good link to common troubleshooting steps:

https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

How to Use

I made the holes wide enough that there shouldn't be as much of an issue with stringing. If you have strings in your holes, just ream them out, or fix your stringing issue. I've printed two of these and the holes came out perfectly.

How do you use a coffee stencil? Simple!

1) Put coffee in vessel
2) Shake up your creamer a lot, so it's bubbly
3) Pour creamer over coffee slowly, so it stays at the top (don't stir!)
4) Leave very little "headroom" at the top - maybe 1/4" or less?
5) Place stencil over the top of the vessel
6) Lightly sprinkle the powder of your choice over the top of the stencil

I like to make sure I sprinkle over the entire stencil, that way I know I'm getting into all the nooks and crannies.

As far as sprinkling goes, I love using little metal mesh teabag balls. They're easy to fill, and do a good job of sifting most powders you'll be using.

If you prefer videos, here's a good one:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M8ugnBwyCgk

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

I love Fusion 360 for design, and Simplify3D for slicing and dicing.

As mentioned earlier, I had an issue with this generation of handles, so I re-worked them. The next stencil will have way more awesome handles - or at least, handles that won't break off easily. Plus, a new surprise feature, and a new accessory for the stencils! (Have I said too much?)
